questions.text: A 45 y/o male presents with recurrent episodes of abdominal pain and persistent heartburn. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy reveals multiple duodenal ulcers. Lab investigations show elevated serum gastrin levels (> 1000 pg/ml). Which features are most likely associated with the patient's condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Presence of gastrin-secreting tumors in the stomach

options.label: B
options.text: Presence of erosive esophagitis and hiatal hernia

options.label: C
options.text: Hyperplasia of parietal cells within the stomach

questions.correct_answer: C. Hyperplasia of parietal cells within the stomach

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with vague abdominal discomfort and early satiety. Imaging reveals a large mass in the gastric fundus. He undergoes surgical resection of the mass, and histopathology confirms a gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST). Which of the following factors is a favorable prognostic indicator of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Features

Good prognosis

Bad prognosis

Tumor size

< 5cm

>10cm (Option A)

Mitotic rate

< 5 per HPF

>10 per HPF

Location

Gastric

Intestinal (Jejunum, Ileum, Rectum) (Option D)

Cell type

Spindle cell type

Epithelioid cell type (Option B)

Mutations

Wild type GIST (Lack mutations in KIT, PDGFR)

Specific PDGFRA mutations, such as the D842V mutation in exon 18

Treatment

Responds to Tyrosine kinase inhibitors.

Resistant to Tyrosine kinase inhibitors.

questions.text: Which of the following markers will help confirm the diagnosis of GIST in C-kit negative cases?
Which of the following is the most common mutation found in GIST (Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor)?

A 55-year-old man with intermittent abdominal pain, nausea, and early satiety has a palpable epigastric mass. Imaging shows a well-defined, heterogeneously enhancing stomach mass, and endoscopic biopsy reveals CD117-positive spindle cells. What is the likely origin of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Cells of origin

Cajal cells

Mutations
  • Most common- c-KIT/CD117
  • Others:
    • PDGFR- beta
    • Succinate dehydrogenase (SDH)- Small baby( Pediatric GIST)

Mechanism

c-KIT mutation- Increase in tyrosinase kinase activity

Treatment
  • Surgery
  • Tyrosine Kinase inhibitors- Imatinib

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with episodes of flushing, sweating, and colicky abdominal pain. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy reveals a yellow-tan intramural mass in the stomach. Biopsy revealed sheets of uniform cells with scant granular cytoplasm. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 48-year-old female presents with recurrent abdominal pain, bloating, and early satiety for the past few months. Endoscopic biopsy revealed lympho-epithelial lesions with infiltration of small lymphoid cells. Which of the following statements is true regarding this condition?

options.label: D
options.text: Presents as discrete small nodules in the GI tract

questions.text: A 45-year-old female has a history of intermittent epigastric discomfort, nausea, and early satiety. Upper endoscopy reveals gastric wall thickening with a leather bottle appearance. Biopsy of the lesion shows signet ring cells infiltrating the gastric mucosa. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Features

Intestinal type Gastric adenocarcinoma (Option A)

Diffuse-type gastric adenocarcinoma (Option B)

Location

Predominantly in the antrum or pyloric region

Diffuse involvement of gastric body and fundus

Risk factors

H. pylori infection, high intake of smoked/pickled foods, smoking, chronic gastritis, old age

CDH1 gene mutation, younger age

Appearance on endoscopy

Ulcerative, polypoid masses (localised growth)

Thickening of gastric wall (due to diffuse infiltration).

Linitis plastica (leather bottle appearance)

Histology

Well-differentiated glandular structures with intestinal metaplasia.

 

 

Signet ring cells and infiltration of poorly cohesive cells into the gastric mucosa.

 

 

Prognosis

Better

Poorer

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with a history of epigastric pain, unintentional weight loss, and early satiety over the past few months. An upper GI endoscopy revealed a nodular mass on the gastric wall, and a biopsy revealed well-differentiated glandular structures with intestinal metaplasia. Which of the following is least likely associated with this condition?

options.label: D
options.text: High intake of smoked or pickled foods

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a recognised risk factor for gastric adenocarcinoma?
Which cells are primarily responsible for secreting neutral mucin that forms a protective layer in the stomach?
questions.explanation:
Cells

Functions
  1. Parietal cells (Option A)

Secrete hydrochloric acid (HCl) and intrinsic factor.
  1. Chief cells (Option B)

Secrete pepsinogen (Inactive precursor of the pepsin).
  1. Foveolar cells

Secrete neutral mucin and form a protective layer over the stomach lining.
  1. Enterochromaffin cells

(Option D)

Release of serotonin and histamine to regulate gastric functions.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with persistent abdominal discomfort, nausea, weight loss, and occasional diarrhoea. He was recently diagnosed with a viral infection. The following gross image of the gastric mucosa is observed upon upper gastrointestinal endoscopy. Which of the following is correct regarding the patient's condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Associated with excessive secretion of TNF-α.

options.label: C
options.text: Increases the risk of gastric carcinoma.

options.label: D
options.text: More common in females and can cause protein-losing enteropathy.

questions.correct_answer: C. Increases the risk of gastric carcinoma.

questions.text: A 58-year-old female presents with recurrent epigastric discomfort and intermittent nausea. Histopathological examination of gastric biopsy samples reveals irregular, cystically dilated, and elongated foveolar glands. She also has a history of untreated H. pylori infection. What type of lesions is most likely to be associated with these findings?

A 60-year-old man on long-term proton pump inhibitor therapy for acid reflux undergoes an upper gastrointestinal endoscopy for recurrent epigastric discomfort. The endoscopy reveals smooth-surfaced lesions in the gastric body and fundus. Which statement about these findings is likely correct?

options.label: A
options.text: PPIs decrease gastrin secretion, reducing the risk of fundic gland polyps

options.label: B
options.text: Fundic gland polyps are commonly associated with H. pylori infection.

options.label: C
options.text: Composed of cystically dilated glands lined by parietal, chief, and foveolar cells.

options.label: D
options.text: Sporadic fundic gland polyps carry a significant risk of neoplasia.

questions.correct_answer: C. Composed of cystically dilated glands lined by parietal, chief, and foveolar cells.

questions.text: Which type of gastritis is associated with a distinctive endoscopic appearance characterised by thickened folds, small nodules, and central aphthous ulceration affecting the entire stomach?

A 45-year-old female presents with chronic epigastric pain, nausea, and occasional vomiting. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy reveals diffuse mucosal atrophy. Biopsy confirms chronic gastritis. Which of the following is a characteristic feature of Chronic Gastritis Type A?

options.label: A
options.text: Predominantly affects the antrum of the stomach

questions.correct_answer: B. Autoimmune destruction of parietal cells
questions.explanation:
Characteristic

Chronic Gastritis Type A

Chronic Gastritis Type B

Location

Fundus and body of the stomach

Antrum and pyloric region of the stomach (Option A)

Aetiology

Autoimmune

H. pylori infection or NSAID use

Pathophysiology

Autoimmune destruction of parietal cells (Option B)

H. pylori-induced inflammation of gastric mucosa (Option C)

Autoantibodies

Autoantibodies against parietal cells and Antibodies against intrinsic factors (↓Vit B12 absorption).

Not autoimmune; may have H. pylori antibodies.

Intrinsic factor

Reduced due to parietal cell destruction.

It may be normal unless atrophic gastritis is present.

Gastric acid production

Autoantibodies against parietal cells lead to decreased/absent HCl secretion and ↑gastrin synthesis.

Normal to increased acid secretion due to H. pylori.

Histological findings

Lymphocytic and plasma cell infiltrate.

Neutrophilic infiltrate, lymphoid follicles.

Complications

Pernicious anaemia, gastric carcinoid, adenocarcinoma.

Peptic ulcers, gastric adenocarcinoma, MALToma.

Risk of gastric carcinoma

Low

Increased, especially with H. pylori infection (Option D)

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents with recurrent epigastric pain and signs of gastrointestinal bleeding. An upper endoscopy reveals gastric ulcers, and a biopsy is performed for further evaluation. Which stain is best for identifying the causative organism in this condition?
Which of the following is NOT a protective factor against Peptic Ulcer Disease?
questions.explanation:
Protective factors

Damaging factors
  • Mucus (Option A)
  • Bicarbonate (Option B)
  • COX 1 (Option C)
  • HCl
  • Pepsin
  • H.pylori

questions.text: A 45-year-old man experiences recurrent upper abdominal pain worsened after meals, unresponsive to over-the-counter antacids. Which of the following is NOT typically a risk factor for the patient’s presentation?

A 55-year-old female with traumatic brain injury undergoes emergency craniotomy and is now intubated in the neurosurgical ICU. She suddenly develops hematemesis despite stabilisation. What is the most likely cause of the patient's bleeding?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer:B) 

Feature

Cushing's Ulcers (Option B)

Curling Ulcers (Option A)

Location

Usually found in the stomach (cardia), oesophagus, or duodenum

Typically occur in the proximal duodenum

Associated condition

Elevated intracranial pressure (e.g., head trauma, intracranial haemorrhage)

Severe burns (involving >30% of body surface area) or trauma

Pathogenesis

Increased vagal activity stimulates gastric acid secretion, leading to ulcer formation.

Result from decreased mucosal blood flow due to systemic hypotension or stress-induced vasoconstriction

Ulcer characteristics

Deep ulcers; increased risk of perforation.

Superficial ulcers.
